Josephine has stood witness to decades of change in our country. She‚Äôs lived through dozens of elections, and still remembers firsthand a time when poll taxes were used to block Black Americans from exercising their right to vote.
Josephine was born in Maidens, Virginia in 1918. Growing up, she attended a one-room school and as the seventh of 13 children, the house her father built for their family was always full.

If libertarians are to succeed at moving politics in a more liberty-oriented direction, then we must build our own brand as far away from Donald Trump as possible. Libertarianism‚Äôs compelling vision for securing individual rights has to get out from under the shadow of Trumpism.

Trump massively gains from this exchange, and libertarianism loses. By neutralizing or co-opting potential libertarian critics, Trump is left largely unchecked with respect to his unlibertarian actions, while libertarianism is falsely and harmfully cast as a relative of Trumpism.

Meanwhile, libertarians have been taken for a ride. It‚Äôs been an almost entirely one-way relationship. Libertarians lend their support and credibility to Trump on many issues, while Trump pays them lip service on those issues and makes mostly inconsequential gestures.

The least principled, least constitutionally aligned members of the GOP now face almost no scrutiny with respect to their policies and records. As long as they say they‚Äôre firmly behind Trump, they‚Äôre good to go, regardless of how much they grow government or violate our rights.

We shouldn‚Äôt confuse Trump‚Äôs anti-establishment rhetoric with anti-establishment actions. He‚Äôs been the greatest gift to establishment politicians like Mitch McConnell and Kevin McCarthy, who needed Trump‚Äôs celebrity to sell their unpopular schemes to the grassroots of the party.
Donald Trump is no libertarian or friend to libertarians. He‚Äôs a national populist whose agenda centers around collective identity, not individual rights.

Trump doesn‚Äôt respect federalism or separation of powers, declaring that ‚Äúwhen somebody is the president of the United States, the authority is total, and that‚Äôs the way it‚Äôs got to be.‚Äù

He consistently undermines local decision making and supports new forms of central planning.
He threatened online speech by signing an executive order on Section 230 in which he sought to rewrite the law and punish private actors for exercising their First Amendment-secured rights.
Trump directed a federal crackdown on vaping products and signed a bill raising the federal tobacco age to 21.

To get funding for his wall, he used unprecedented claims of emergency power to usurp Congress‚Äôs authority over appropriations, and now he‚Äôs using eminent domain to seize private land to speed up construction.

Trump has spent billions of taxpayer dollars bailing out the agriculture industry that he harmed with his own trade policies, and he signed a bill extending the cronyist Export-Import Bank for seven years.
He supported government central planning in the labor market by taking measures to further limit legal immigration.

Trump raised taxes by charging Americans billions of dollars in tariffs, and he negotiated a trade deal (USMCA) that actually increases the federal government‚Äôs interference in trade between individuals.

He says he will ‚Äúalways protect your Second Amendment right,‚Äù but he banned bump stocks, expressed support for red flag laws, and declared that we should ‚Äútake the guns first, go through due process second.‚Äù

Trump rails against surveillance of his own associates, but he signed FISA 702 and a Patriot Act reauthorization, hired DoJ leadership that supports warrantless surveillance, and attacked private companies for refusing to build government backdoors into every person‚Äôs phone.

Trump also revived the federal death penalty. He‚Äôs executed more people in the last few months than his predecessors had in more than 60 years.

He detained an American citizen without charge or trial for over a year.

Trump‚Äôs AGs have also worked to impose the federal government on state and local criminal justice systems by attacking local efforts at reform.

He has fought federal policing reform, and he sent federal police to interfere in matters within local officials‚Äô jurisdictions.

Trump loves to tout his record on criminal justice reform, but he appointed attorneys general that have expanded civil asset forfeiture and ended Department of Justice policies that were intended to limit marijuana enforcement and reduce harsh criminal sentencing.

He also bypassed Congress to push through weapons sales to foreign countries, including billions of dollars in arms to Saudi Arabia‚Äîand he used the prospect of lucrative arms sales to excuse the Saudis after their government‚Äôs murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

Trump has overseen a significant increase in U.S. military spending and brags about how much is being spent on military equipment. https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1213689342272659456 QT @realDonaldTrump The United States just spent Two Trillion Dollars on Military Equipment. We are the biggest and by far the BEST in the World! If Iran attacks an American Base, or any American, we will be sending some of that brand new beautiful equipment their way...and without hesitation!

Trump sometimes acts like he‚Äôs opposed to the military-industrial complex, even suggesting the Pentagon wants ‚Äúto do nothing but fight wars‚Äù in order to keep defense contractors happy, but no one has been a bigger booster of the defense industry than Trump.

He also vetoed measures passed by Congress to limit U.S. involvement in Yemen‚Äôs civil war, block weapons sales that support it, and prevent war with Iran. More than half of Trump‚Äôs vetoes (five of eight) have been against measures trying to limit U.S. military aggression abroad.

Despite repeating over and over that he wants to end wars and bring home the troops, Trump actually increased our military presence in the Middle East and launched attacks in multiple countries without congressional approval‚Äîrecord strikes in places like Afghanistan and Somalia.
After claiming he would wipe out the national debt in eight years, he signed massive spending increases and created the highest ever federal debt‚Äîeven before the coronavirus pandemic began.
Donald Trump wants to win the support of libertarians, but his actual record on expanding the federal government and eroding liberty is appalling.
